acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since the 48-hour LC50 = 0.16mg/L for crustaceans (Daphnia magna) (Hazard Assessment Report (CERI, NITE), 2005), the substance was classified into Category 1.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the LD50 of > 2000mg/kg in the tests that complied with OECD TG 404, and based on the fact that no mortality occurred (SIDS (accessed June 2008), EU-RAR (2002)), the substance was classified into "Not classified".

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on its rat LC50 > 180mg/L/1h, which is equivalent to 45mg/L/4h (mist) (EU-RAR (2002)), the substance was classified into "Not classified".

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on several rat LD50 values documented (> 2000mg/kg, 2260mg/kg (male), 2600mg/kg (female) (SIDS (accessed June 2008), EU-RAR (2002)), the substance was classified into "Not classified" in accordance with JIS classification criteria (Category 5 in the United Nations classification).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its classification for acute toxicity is Category 1 and it is not rapidly degradable (SRC: BioWin V4.10), the substance was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification is not possible due to lack of in vivo data, although negative results were available from in vitro tests (SIDS (2000)).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing chlorine, which is bonded to nitrogen (but not carbon or hydrogen) via ionic bond. Not oxidizing due to the ionic bond.

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: In reproductive and developmental tests using rats that were orally administered (OECD TG 421), the following were observed at high doses: prolonged pre-mating period, lowered gestation rates (shown in 6 of 9 rats), and fewer maternal rats that gave birth (shown in 5 of 6 rats) (Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO)). In addition, general toxicity, such as decreased body weight gain and labored breathing, were detected in parental animals of both sexes at the same high doses (Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO)). From these results, the substance was classified into Category 2.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.classification: Category 1  Note: the substance of technical grade is in Category 1
serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale:
The substance was classified into Category 1 based on the documented cases of severe damage (EU-RAR (2002)) resulted from the tests in which the substance was applied to rabbits' eyes (OECD TG 405).
In addition, since the substance of technical grade (77%) was associated with skin corrosion, it was classified into Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.classification: Category 2  Note: the substance of technical grade is in Category 1
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale:
In 4-hour skin irritation tests using rabbits, erythema of mild to moderate severity were observed in all animals treated with pure (97%) testing substance. However, these symptoms disappeared within 14 days and no edema was detected. In addition, average scores of Draize tests at 24, 48 and 72 hours after the application were 2, 1, and 0.3, respectively (EU-RAR, vol.14, 2002). From these results, the substance was classified into Category 2.
In addition, after the application of the substance of technical grade (77%), moderate irritation was observed, which increased in severity and developed into severe necrosis after 14 days of observation (EU-RAR (vol. 14, 2002)). Based on this result, the substance was classified into Category 1.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: No positive reactions were detected in both skin sensitization tests using guinea pigs (maximization tests and epicutaneous tests) and repeated sensitization patch tests on 136 humans (SIDS (accessed in June 2008), EU-RAR (2002)). Since no signs of skin sensitization were observed, the substance was classified into "Not classified".

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: The 28-day repeated oral administration test using rats provides the only repeated exposure data useful for toxicity evaluation. In this test, significant effects on the adrenal gland were reported at 500mg/kg/day: increased weight, hypertrophy, discoloration of its surface, peripheral granulocyte infiltration, and hemorrhage (EU-RAR (2002)). Its NOAEL was 100mg/kg/day. Since the upper limit of Category 2 guidance values for 28-day exposure period is 321mg/kg/day (100*90/28), which falls between the NOAEL (100mg/kg/day) and the toxic dose (500mg/kg/day), its effects at the cutoff value cannot be determined. Therefore, classification is not possible based on these data alone.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In acute toxicity tests using rats that underwent oral route and inhalation exposure, symptoms of systematic toxicity were observed (SIDS (accessed June 2008) EU-RAR (2002)). However, doses used were higher than the guidance values. Since the effects of the substance at doses within the range of guidance values were not documented, classification is not possible.
